title.text: USFD2: Annotating Temporal Expresions and TLINKs for TempEval-2

abstractContent.text: We describe the University of Sheffield system used in the TempEval-2 challenge, USFD2.
The challenge requires the automatic identification of temporal entities and relations in text.

entities.text: automatic identification of temporal entities and relations in text

abstractContent.text: USFD2 identifies and anchors temporal expressions, and also attempts two of the four temporal relation assignment tasks.

A rule-based system picks out and anchors temporal expressions, and a maximum entropy classifier assigns temporal link labels, based on features that include descriptions of associated temporal signal words.
USFD2 identified temporal expressions successfully, and correctly classified their type in 90% of cases.
Determining the relation between an event and time expression in the same sentence was performed at 63% accuracy, the second highest score in this part of the challenge.

introductionContent.text: The TempEval-2 () challenge proposes six tasks.

Our system tackles three of these: task A -identifying time expressions, assigning TIMEX3 attribute values, and anchoring them; task C -determining the temporal relation between an event and time in the same sentence; and task E -determining the temporal relation between two main events in consecutive sentences.
For our participation in the task, we decided to employ both rule-and ML-classifierbased approaches.

Temporal expressions are dealt with by sets of rules and regular expressions, and relation labelling performed by NLTK's 1 maximum entropy classifier with rule-based processing applied during feature generation.

The features (described in full in Section 2) included attributes See http://www.nltk.org/ . from the TempEval-2 training data annotation, augmented by features that can be directly derived from the annotated texts.

There are two main aims of this work: (1) to create a rule-based temporal expression annotator that includes knowledge from work published since GUTime) and measure its performance, and (2) to measure the performance of a classifier that includes features based on temporal signals.
Our entry to the challenge, USFD2, is a successor to USFD).

In the rest of this paper, we will describe how USFD2 is constructed (Section 2), and then goon to discuss its overall performance and the impact of some internal parameters on specific TempEval tasks.
Regarding classifiers, we found that despite using identical feature sets across relation classification tasks, performance varied significantly.
We also found that USFD2 performance trends with TempEval-2 did not match those seen when classifiers were trained on other data while performing similar tasks.
The paper closes with comments about future work.
